Title.evidence: Effect of Obesity on Outcomes of Lumbar Disc Herniation Treatment: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with patients from the Spine Patient Outcomes Research Trial.

Participants.evidence: Participants were classified as nonobese (BMI <30 kg/m², n = 854) and obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m², n = 336).

Intervention.evidence: obese patients demonstrated less improvement in primary outcomes compared to nonobese patients in both treatment groups.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effect of obesity on outcomes following treatment for symptomatic lumbar disc herniation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were Short Form-36 physical function and bodily pain scores, and the Oswestry Disability Index, measured at baseline and up to four years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not detailed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding of outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians was not specified.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were classified as nonobese (BMI <30 kg/m², n = 854) and obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m², n = 336).

Result_Outcome.evidence: obese patients had lower improvements in Short Form-36 physical function (37.3 vs. 47.7, p < 0.001), bodily pain (44.2 vs. 50.0, p = 0.005), and Oswestry Disability Index (−33.7 vs. −40.1, p < 0.001).
